item.title: Biden Administration Clamps Down on China’s Access to Chip Technology
item.description: The White House issued sweeping restrictions on selling semiconductors and chip-making equipment to China, an attempt to curb the country’s access to critical technologies.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A semiconductor factory in Nantong, China. New limits on sales of semiconductor technology aim to slow the progress of Chinese military programs.

item.title: China Is the Wild Card in the Energy War With Russia
item.description: Slower growth in China has braked the rise in world energy prices and Russian riches, but Beijing has also stepped up its purchases of Russian fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: CFOTO/Future Publishing, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A Sinopec plant in Nanjing, China. Sinopec is the world’s largest oil refining, gas and petrochemical conglomerate.

item.title: The Job Market Has Been Like Musical Chairs. Will the Music Stop?
item.description: Many workers grew comfortable thinking they had plenty of options. Now “everybody’s feeling the whiplash,” and anxiety is rising.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: As Debbie Ricks pursued her dream career as a photojournalist, the restaurant jobs that she thought would be a safety net started disappearing.

item.title: Wages continued to climb, keeping the Fed on course.
item.description: Despite slowing slightly, wage growth remains strong. Fed officials are likely to see that as a green light to stay focused on cooling the economy.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: Markets Fall as Investors Assess the State of Jobs and Inflation
item.description: Fresh data on the labor market solidified investors’ expectations that the Federal Reserve will need to keep raising interest rates aggressively.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and Isabella Simonetti

item.title: ‘They Are in a Panic’: Ukraine’s Troops Size Up the Enemy
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers are exulting in their smashing of Russian lines in the northeast. They engaged enemy troops up close, and gained confidence from it.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Says Risk of Nuclear ‘Armageddon’ Is Highest Since 1962 Crisis
item.description: The president’s blunt warnings, highly unusual for an American president, were delivered informally to a group of Democratic donors in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden boarding Marine One in New York City on Thursday night. “We are trying to figure out: What is Putin’s off ramp?” he said at a fund-raiser there.

item.title: How a Dog’s Killing Turned Brooklyn Progressives Against One Another
item.description: After a sudden confrontation that left a golden retriever dead, neighbors came together online to support the owner of the dog. But then things changed.
item.dc:creator: John Leland
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times

item.title: Justice Dept. Is Said to Believe Trump Has More Documents
item.description: Conversations between department officials and the former president’s representatives have underscored investigators’ skepticism about his cooperation and exposed a rift among his lawyers.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman and Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department’s continued effort to retrieve documents from former President Donald J. Trump that may still be missing has led to a divide among his lawyers.

item.title: Five Takeaways From the Arizona Senate Debate
item.description: Mark Kelly and Blake Masters fought over familiar ground, including abortion, the border and the 2020 election, as they were pressed to clarify their positions.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Ross D. Franklin/Associated Press
item.media:description: Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, left, with Blake Masters, his Republican rival in his race for re-election, before their debate on Thursday night in Phoenix.

item.title: In Record Numbers, Venezuelans Risk a Deadly Trek to the U.S. Border
item.description: Two crises are converging at the perilous land bridge known as the Darién Gap: the economic and humanitarian disaster underway in South America, and the bitter fight over immigration policy in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Eric Adams Declares State of Emergency in New York City to Respond to Migrant Crisis
item.description: The number of people in the New York City main shelter system has exceeded 61,000, nearing a record for the city.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Adams said the city had been “overwhelmed” by the nearly 17,000 migrants who have arrived since April.

item.title: Can McKinsey Solve the NYC Trash Problem?
item.description: Maybe the trash problem in New York will be solved with color-coded garbage cans designed by expensive consultants. Or maybe the problem is much deeper.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Sebastian Mejias for The New York Times
item.media:description: A typical sidewalk these days in New York City.

item.title: A Canadian Family Is Seeing the World Before Their Children’s Vision Falters
item.description: A Canadian family is on a yearlong journey across Asia and Africa because three of their four children have an eye condition that causes blindness.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: We Had to Force the Constitution to Accommodate Democracy, and It Shows
item.description: We tend to equate American democracy with the Constitution, but our history makes it clear that the two are in tension with each other.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: A Lost Manuscript Shows the Fire Barack Obama Couldn’t Reveal on the Campaign Trail
item.description: At Harvard Law, he wrote a blistering manifesto he never published. Its searing advice could help Democrats escape their current political quagmire.
item.dc:creator: Timothy Shenk
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Has The Fed Gone Too Far on Interest Rates?
item.description: We really don’t want the Fed to do a Lee County.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; photograph by Javier Zayas, via Getty Images

item.title: Putin and M.B.S. Are Laughing at Us
item.description: Putin’s motivation for OPEC’s price hike is no mystery.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Kevin Lamarque/Reuters

item.title: ‘It’s Like a War Out There.’ Iran’s Women Haven’t Been This Angry in a Generation.
item.description: The gap between the freedoms and opportunities enjoyed by the system’s affiliated elite and those of ordinary Iranians has never been so wide.
item.dc:creator: Azadeh Moaveni
item.media:credit: Richard Tomkins/Associated Press
item.media:description: Iranian women demonstrating for equal rights in 1979.

item.title: The N.Y.U. Chemistry Students Shouldn’t Have Needed That Petition
item.description: High-stakes weed-out classes like organic chemistry are relics of an age when college students were much more uniformly privileged.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Calarco
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: Ninety Years Ago, This Book Tried to Warn Us
item.description: A 1933 novel on the Nazi rise to power is still relevant today.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Here’s Hoping Elon Musk Destroys Twitter
item.description: The best thing the platform can do for society is implode.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Jim Watson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: The Power of Paxlovid
item.description: The underuse of Covid treatments is leading to many needless deaths.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Alex Merto

item.title: What Are Tactical Nuclear Weapons, and What if Russia Uses Them?
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin has threatened to fire a particular kind of arm in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Nina Feldman, Luke Vander Ploeg, Michael Simon Johnson, Liz O. Baylen, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Maksim Blinov
item.media:description: Mr. Putin’s potential use of nuclear weapons in the war could usher the world into an unpredictable new age.

item.title: ‘The Run-Up’: Can Democrats Catch up to Years of Republican Unity?
item.description: The overturning of Roe v. Wade has given Democrats a rallying issue to mobilize around before the midterms. Can they catch up to years of Republican unity?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: Our TV critic recommends a new show about shipwrecks, another about chain saws and a South African murder mystery.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.category: Recipes for Love and Murder (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Discovery

item.title: His Mom Labored on a Winery Under Apartheid. Now, He Owns One.
item.description: Paul Siguqa grew up hating wineries because his mother toiled in their fields. But last year he opened the only fully Black-owned vineyard in Franschhoek, one of South Africa’s most prestigious wine towns.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Tommy Trenchard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Siguqa, owner of the Klein Goederust winery, inspecting a glass of his cabernet-merlot blend.

item.title: Ron DeSantis’s Wife, Casey, Has High-Profile Role After Florida Hurricane
item.description: Casey DeSantis has led a state effort to raise money for relief efforts in Ian’s wake, appealing for donations during her husband’s news briefings.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Casey DeSantis visited the Pine Island, Fla., Fire Department on Monday amid the response to Hurricane Ian, which slammed Florida last week.

item.title: Judy Tenuta, Accordion-Playing ‘Love Goddess’ of Stand-Up Comedy, Dies at 72
item.description: Ms. Tenuta rose to prominence with an outlandish act in the 1980s and became one of the most prominent women comedians.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:credit: Ron Galella Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Judy Tenuta, dressed for comedy in 1989. She dubbed herself “Aphrodite of the Accordion,” among other titles.

item.title: In Algeria, Veiled From the World, Past and Future Are Shrouded, Too
item.description: A land of thwarted potential, the country fends off outside influences, political change and some of its own history.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Ludovic Marin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Santa Cruz Chapel in Oran, Algeria, last month. For the ossified politico-military establishment that runs the country, tourism and foreign investment are suspect, as are theaters, cinemas or book stores.

item.title: How to Surf on the East Coast
item.description: Autumn may be the season of big swells, but the smaller waves found year-round near East Coast cities are perfect for beginners who want to give surfing a try.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Fogarty
item.media:credit: Yuvraj Khanna for The New York Times

item.title: Balance Exercises to Improve Your Strength
item.description: This simple, often neglected skill can pay huge dividends later in life.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Achauer
item.media:credit: Sarah Karlan for The New York Times

item.title: 6 Ways to Level Up Your Daily Walk
item.description: Experts say Americans are taking more walks than before the pandemic. Here are some ways to turn your neighborhood stroll in to an exciting workout.
item.dc:creator: Emily Pennington
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Pull-Up Techniques for Everyone
item.description: The trick is to break the movement into pieces and train with patience and deliberateness.
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Ben Rayner for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s a simple exercise that’s really hard to do,” said Chilasa King, a New York powerlifter and coach. But doing them is “an amazing feeling.”

item.title: What is 'Body Neutrality' and Can It Change Your Work Out?
item.description: The key to staying active long term may be to care less about how you look and more about how you feel.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Cowles
item.media:credit: Illustration by Yang Kim; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: In ‘A Friend of the Family,’ Jake Lacy Breaks Character
item.description: Known for playing nice guys, the actor won acclaim as a privileged jerk in “The White Lotus.” In a new Peacock drama, he goes even darker.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.category: A Friend of the Family (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Nathan Bajar for The New York Times
item.media:description: “There wasn’t a need to go into his thoughts,” Lacy said of Berchtold. “Because my point of view on his thoughts is so rightfully so filled with judgment.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
